channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Formula One Chief Bernie Ecclestone Settles Bribery Case for $100 Million
item.description: A German judge agreed to let Mr. Ecclestone pay a $100 million penalty in return for quashing a criminal case of bribery that could have sent him to jail for up to 10 years.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:description: The $100 million payment reflected the extent of the fortune Bernie Ecclestone has made from Formula One.

item.title: Earthquake Death Toll Rises to Nearly 600 in China
item.description: The death toll from the quake that struck Yunnan Province on Sunday has jumped to 589 as rescuers reached isolated villages and recovered the bodies of 179 more victims, the state media reported
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: New Insider Attacks Target the Police in Afghanistan
item.description: Two assaults left 11 officers in southern Afghanistan dead as the authorities were still grappling with the assassination of a top American general.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: Letter From India: The Reality of English's Role in India
item.description: Protests over the use of English in a civil-service exam highlight the complex role the language plays in the country's social makeup.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH

item.title: Oscar Pistorius Trial Judge Overcame Apartheid
item.description: The judge in the Oscar Pistorius murder trial is that rarity in the South African judicial system: a black woman. And she holds all the cards.
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: For Chinese Officials at Risk of Corruption, a View of Life Behind Bars
item.description: As part of a wider anticorruption campaign, the National Development and Reform Commission has sent some 200 “high risk” personnel for visits of prisons that hold officials convicted of graft.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In a Xinjiang City, No Room on the Bus for Those With Veils or Long Beards
item.description: The authorities in a city in the western Chinese region of Xinjiang have banned long beards and apparel with Islamic symbols on public buses as part of an effort to increase security and ensure stability, a state-run newspaper has reported.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Uighur women at the Sunday bazaar in Kashgar, Xinjiang.

item.title: U.S. Drone Strike Kills 6 in Pakistani Tribal Area
item.description: The strike in North Waziristan was the latest in a series by C.I.A.-operated drone aircraft to coincide with focus of a major offensive by the Pakistani military.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Andy Coulson, Former Murdoch Editor, Accused of Perjury
item.description: Adding to the legal tangle spreading from the phone hacking scandal, Mr. Coulson was accused of lying to a court in 2010.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Prosecutors in Scotland on Wednesday accused Andy Coulson, a former newspaper editor and senior adviser to Prime Minister David Cameron, of committing perjury in a trial in 2010.

item.title: Bush Urges Renewed Fight Against Deadly Diseases in Africa
item.description: Former President George W. Bush, speaking at a health forum in Washington, spoke of “the beginning of the end of AIDS.”
item.category: President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: European Spacecraft Pulls Alongside Comet
item.description: After 10 years and a journey of four billion miles, the Rosetta probe arrived at its destination for the first extended, close examination of a comet.
item.dc:creator: By KENNETH CHANG
item.media:description: The comet, as photographed by the European Space Agency’s Rosetta spacecraft, is 2.5 miles wide.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Jen Lin-Liu on Noodles and Their Origins
item.description: Ms. Lin-Liu documented her adventures tracing the history of the noodle on the ancient Silk Road in her book “On the Noodle Road: From Beijing to Rome, with Love and Pasta,” which has just come out in paperback.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: A noodle maker shows off his skills in a pulled noodle restaurant in Lanzhou.

item.title: Bangladesh Begins Manhunt for Owners of Capsized Ferry
item.description: The authorities have charged the ferry’s owners with culpable homicide, a charge that can bring the death sentence or life imprisonment.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Police officers display photographs of passengers who went missing after an overloaded ferry capsized in Bangladesh's Padma River.

item.title: Mayor of London Plans to Run for Parliament
item.description: Boris Johnson’s decision opens the possibility that he could one day succeed Prime Minister David Cameron as leader of the Conservative Party.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: North Korea Declines Invitation to Papal Mass in Seoul
item.description: North Korea has decided not to send a delegation to a Mass to be led by Pope Francis during his South Korea visit this month, officials said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why Help China’s Military Progress?
item.description: With tensions rising in Asia, Washington must view its military exchanges with Beijing through the lens of American security interests.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By STEVE COHEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Stealth Censorship in Venezuela
item.description: How the Maduro government has outsourced repression of the media to the private sector.
item.dc:creator: By DANIEL LANSBERG-RODRÍGUEZ

item.title: No Clear Winner as Scots Debate Independence
item.description: With a vote nearing, neither side produced a knockout punch during a two-hour televised debate.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Militant Jewish Group Confronts Protesters in a Tense France
item.description: Leaders of the group, an offshoot of the Jewish Defense League, preach a muscular defense against anti-Semitism, but critics accuse them of provocation.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Jailed Uighur Scholar Rejects China’s Separatism Charges as ‘Distorted’
item.description: Ilham Tohti, who has been held nearly seven months, denied being the leader of a group seeking an independent Uighur homeland, his lawyers said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: World Briefing: Philippines: Fishermen Sentenced
item.description: A court on Tuesday found 12 Chinese fishermen guilty of illegal fishing in Philippine waters, sending them to jail for six to 12 years.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Bulgaria: New Government Appointed
item.description: Moving Tuesday to quell a deep political crisis, Bulgaria appointed a law professor as interim prime minister until national elections in October.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Cease-Fire Between Syrian Insurgents and Lebanese Army Ends Quickly
item.description: Renewed shelling and bombing around the border town of Arsal raised new alarms about the spread of Syria’s civil war.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Afghan Civilians Killed in Airstrike by American-Led Coalition
item.description: The attack, which killed at least four civilians, prompted a sharp rebuke from President Hamid Karzai, who has long bristled at the deaths of Afghans in foreign-led military operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and AHMAD SHAKIB

item.title: Argentina: Man Located After 37 Years
item.description: The head of a human rights organization that searches for hundreds of babies stolen by Argentina’s military dictatorship decades ago has located her grandson after 37 years.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT
